subject: Re: [junit] Methods that does not return value
msgSnippet: ... I would strongly suggest not to do that.  There are terrible side effects to opening up the internals of an object -- keep its internals private and
messageBody:
On 11 Jun 2003 18:56:13 -0500, "Brett Neumeier" <random@...> said:
> On Wed, 2003-06-11 at 18:11, balakrishnan sengodan wrote:
> > Jason: Thanks for your reply. As you have mentioned in
> > your reply, we need to write a getCount() mthod to get
> > the value of the "counter". We do not want to do this.
> > Without "GET" method, is there any way we can get the
> > value of the "counter".
>
> Well, you could change "counter" to be package visible, or public,
> depending on where the test is. Is that too obvious?
>
>
> --
> Brett Neumeier <random@...>

I would strongly suggest not to do that. There are terrible side effects
to opening up the internals of an object -- keep its internals private
and provide an interface to manipulate the object in a regulated fashion.
Personally, I favor immutable objects. I very rarely will allow for an
object's state to be changed once it is created. If I need it in another
state I write a clone behavior to give me a new object with a new state.
The example I gave of the Counter (a brain dead object) is at least one
case though where I would probably not use the immutable pattern.

=jason
--
=jason
[:question | ^One]
